title: Introduction to Ships, Ports and Terminals
headline: A free online course that covers general cargo ships, the classification of charters and signing charter agreements.
description: This free online course on ships, ports and terminals introduces you to the importance of ships in transportation, as well as the basics of general cargo vessels. You will learn about the different classifications of charters, as well as the concept of voyage chartering, and registration processes for ships. Start this course today to improve your understanding of maritime operations in ships, ports as well as terminals.
courseDescription:
Introduction to Ships, Ports and Terminals is a free online course that begins by introducing you to the reason why ships are important in transportation, as well as the basics of general cargo vessels. It will also ground you in the importance of the intact stability criteria and cargo-carrying capacity for a general cargo vessel. The different aspects of ship operations in carrying out maritime logistic processes, as well as chartering agreements, will also be covered in this course.

The material then explains the different classifications of charters, as well as the concept of voyage chartering and registration processes for ships. You will learn about the maritime chain of transportation, as well as the various segments of the shipping market. This course also will teach you the roles of the shipping company or carrier, as well as the main assets of the freight forwarder.

Furthermore, you will get familiar with the importance of ports and terminals, as well as the complexity of global port operations. Learn about the different classifications of ports and terminals, as well as the various differences between them. This free online course will be of great interest to those involved in maritime supply-chain logistics, moving cargo by sea, and the general operations of ships, ports and terminals.

Start Course Now

slides:
• Learning Outcomes 
  • Upon the successful completion of this module, you should be able to:
    • Explain why ships are important in transportation. 
    • Explain the basics of a general cargo vessel.
    • Describe the intact stability criteria for a general cargo vessel.
    • Analyze the ventilation requirement of cargo during transit.
    • Describe the cargo carrying capacity of a general cargo vessel.
    • Outline the factors to be considered prior to loading general cargo.
  • Why Ships?
  • Logistics is all about using the right type of resources for the right results. Ships have undergone significant specialization in the 20th century, with each type having unique features suited for the carriage of different types of commerce. A basic understanding of ship types is a pre-requisite to entering the growing field of maritime logistics. Here is a table which explains each ship types and their unique features.

  • Did you know?

    Did you know?

    Did you know? The best known of the Viking ships is the Drakkar, the dragon-ship. The name came from the form of the head of this ship which represented a dragon head. This ship was very large and was used only for war. They required up to 60 rowers. It was very expensive to keep such a boat. It appeared around 1050 and King Olaf Tryggvasson is known to have had the most numerous fleet.

  • Carriage and Stowage
  • Once the cargo is loaded onboard, it becomes the responsibility of the carrier, to carry the cargo and discharge it safely. In order to ensure safe delivery, the cargo has to be stowed appropriately to avoid any damage during the course of the voyage. Preparation for a good stowage has to be done in advance of loading the vessel. Carriage of cargo must be in accordance with the stability criteria at all stages during the voyage.

    Stowage is an important aspect of cargo carriage. The principal factors considered for proper cargo stowage are the safety of the ship and all on board, the safety of cargo and port rotation.

    To ensure the safety of the ship you must:
    • Stow the cargo, keeping in mind the stability characteristics of the vessel
    • Avoid excessive bending or shearing stresses while loading
    • Keep in mind the weather conditions during the loaded voyage
    • Follow the load line or any special port requirements
    • Position the cargo properly for easy securing of the hatch covers, doors to spaces, and others
    • Keep in mind the stacking height of the cargo for clear visibility during navigation and watch-keeping
    • In conjunction with junior cargo officers, the Chief Officer should ensure that all cargo is stowed correctly and secured in the stowed position against all expected ship movement when at sea
    • When hazardous parcels, live stock, or valuables are loaded, documentation on such cargoes shall be obtained and administered by the Chief Officer
    • To prevent cargo handlers or stevedores from falling in the space between the bulkheads and the stowed cargo, precautions such as suitable rails, grids or nets should be erected, especially where vessels have been built with corrugated bulkheads

  • Carriage and Stowage
  • Once the cargo is loaded onboard, it becomes the responsibility of the carrier, to carry the cargo and discharge it safely. In order to ensure safe delivery, the cargo has to be stowed appropriately to avoid any damage during the course of the voyage. Preparation for a good stowage has to be done in advance of loading the vessel. Carriage of cargo must be in accordance with the stability criteria at all stages during the voyage.

    Stowage is an important aspect of cargo carriage. The principal factors considered for proper cargo stowage are the safety of the ship and all on board, the safety of cargo and port rotation.

    To ensure the safety of the ship you must:
    • Stow the cargo, keeping in mind the stability characteristics of the vessel
    • Avoid excessive bending or shearing stresses while loading
    • Keep in mind the weather conditions during the loaded voyage
    • Follow the load line or any special port requirements
    • Position the cargo properly for easy securing of the hatch covers, doors to spaces, and others
    • Keep in mind the stacking height of the cargo for clear visibility during navigation and watch-keeping
    • In conjunction with junior cargo officers, the Chief Officer should ensure that all cargo is stowed correctly and secured in the stowed position against all expected ship movement when at sea
    • When hazardous parcels, live stock, or valuables are loaded, documentation on such cargoes shall be obtained and administered by the Chief Officer
    • To prevent cargo handlers or stevedores from falling in the space between the bulkheads and the stowed cargo, precautions such as suitable rails, grids or nets should be erected, especially where vessels have been built with corrugated bulkheads

  • Oil, Chemical and Gas Tankers
  • Various liquid cargoes are transported by sea on tankers. There are two basic types of oil tankers. One is the crude oil tanker which carries mostly a single grade of crude oil. Some of the ULCC's (ultra-large crude carriers) can be up to 500,000 Deadweight.

    The other type of tanker, as mentioned earlier, is the product carriers which can carry different grades of cargo at the same time. They are generally smaller than the crude oil tankers. Most of these liquids are stable at ambient temperature. LPG and LNG are two major types, which are exceptions. LNG is cooled to – 263°C to be maintained in liquid form.

  • Variety of Bulks Carriers 
  • There are a large variety of bulk carriers at present. They range from small 100 metres long to massive 350,000 tonnes capacity. Modern-day bulk carriers are characterised by a single screw type vessel with a high block coefficient. It should have low water flow resistance which will enhance its power. Further, the flow of water towards the rudder and propeller should be sufficient, considering the body shape.

    A solid bulk cargo means the goods which are solids in particle or granular form, with or without moisture. They are generally homogeneous in composition and loaded directly into a vessel's cargo spaces without bagging or packaging. Coal, sulphur, ores, fertilisers and grains are some of the cargoes carried in bulk.

  • Features of Multipurpose Ships 
    • Multipurpose ships are appropriately named. They are designed and built to carry a variety of cargoes and are therefore extremely adaptable and flexible.

      As they are designed to carry all the types of cargoes associated with an infrastructure project, multipurpose ships have the capability to handle cargo as diverse as roll-on/roll-off cargo, containers, bulk liquid and dry bulk parcels. The ability to carry a diversity of cargoes aboard a single ship gives the carrier access to multiple opportunities for revenue

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

    • Due to the demand for flexibility, a multipurpose ship has its own heavy-lift gear and is designed with handy cargo spaces below deck enabling it to carry bulk liquid, dry bulk parcels or ro-ro cargoes. Multipurpose ships are designed with wide and long open hatchways often leading to a tween deck with access to a lower hold, which have a strengthened and flat bottom (also called a tank top). These ships also have the ability to handle some containers on deck

  • Ro-Ro ships
  • Roll on Roll off ships is meant to carry vehicles of various types. Vehicles are driven into or from the ship through ramps fitted at the bow, stern or on the sides. There are many decks available for parking the vehicles. From the main deck, internal ramps leading to various decks facilitate the movements of vehicles inside the ship.

    Spaces for dining, entertainment and other activities are available. For Ro-Ro ships engaged in long passages, have accommodation for their passengers. 
  • Passenger Ships
  • Passenger ships are characterized by their luxurious nature. From the outside view to interiors, the theme is to attract and entertain the passengers. Most part of the ship is occupied by accommodation, restaurants and entertainment area. Very little space is available for cargo.

    Sub-divisions and remotely operated watertight doors have increased the damage stability of passenger ships. Materials used in accommodation along with automatic fire detection and fire fighting arrangements, fire safety is greatly improved.

    Resent disasters involving passenger ships has caused more stringent regulations covering the construction and operation of passenger ships.
  • Did you know? The best known of the Viking ships is the Drakkar, the dragon-ship. The name came from the form of the head of this ship which represented a dragon head. This ship was very large and was used only for war. They required up to 60 rowers. It was very expensive to keep such a boat. It appeared around 1050 and King Olaf Tryggvasson is known to have had the most numerous fleet.

  • Introduction to Container Ships 
  • These are single-deck ships without any hoper tanks. The hatch openings are wide to facilitate the loading of the containers directly into the holds without the assistance of forklifts on the tank top. Many of them have cell guides fitted inside the hold to reduce the number of stevedores and for quick loading. Hatch covers are strengthened to accept containers on top.

    Special arrangements are made for Reefer containers and water-cooled reefer containers. They are generally gearless, except ships visiting smaller ports where shore crane is not available. Speed of Container vessels is in the range of 18 and 25. Container vessels are known for their punctuality and quick turnaround.

    Shipping lines implemented various unitisation measures in order to reduce theft and discharge the same amount of cargo, which was loaded at the load port. Pre-slinging of cargoes, palletisation, barge-carrying ships, ro-ro ships and containerisation are all examples of unitisation.

    You will find most of the goods are transported in containers today and the container ship is the heart of intermodal transportation. Containerisation is a system of packing smaller parcels into one larger package for the ease of handling during transportation.   • Changes to Container Ships 
  • Container ships have been getting bigger since they began operating in liner services over 50 years ago because the increased size produces increased operating efficiency and improved environmental performance.

    Some of the world's biggest container ships are about 1,300 feet long - that's nearly 400 meters or the distance around an Olympic running track - with a maximum width of 180 feet (55 meters). Their engines weigh 2,300 tons, their propellers 130 tons, and there are twenty-one storeys between their bridge and their engine room. They can be operated by teams of just thirteen people and a sophisticated computer system and carry an astonishing 11,000, 20-foot containers. 

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • If that number of containers were loaded onto a train it would need to be 44 miles or 71 kilometres long. And now, as the graph depicts, there are ships even larger than that in operation.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • If that number of containers were loaded onto a train it would need to be 44 miles or 71 kilometres long. And now, as the graph depicts, there are ships even larger than that in operation.
  • Changes to Container Ships 
  • Container ships have been getting bigger since they began operating in liner services over 50 years ago because the increased size produces increased operating efficiency and improved environmental performance.

    Some of the world's biggest container ships are about 1,300 feet long - that's nearly 400 meters or the distance around an Olympic running track - with a maximum width of 180 feet (55 meters). Their engines weigh 2,300 tons, their propellers 130 tons, and there are twenty-one storeys between their bridge and their engine room. They can be operated by teams of just thirteen people and a sophisticated computer system and carry an astonishing 11,000, 20-foot containers.

  • Lesson Summary
    • Logistics is all about using the right type of resources for the right results. Ships have undergone significant specialization in the 20th century, with each type having unique features suited for the carriage of different types of commerce.
    • General cargo ships are the oldest type of cargo ships. The basic concept of these ships being the carriage of all type of general cargoes together. 
    • General cargo ships carry various forms of cargo. The capacity of a cargo hold is expressed differently for different types of cargo. 
    • Carriage of cargo must be in accordance with the stability criteria at all stages during the voyage.
    • Stowage is an important aspect of cargo carriage. The principal factors considered for proper cargo stowage are the safety of the ship and all on board, the safety of cargo and port rotation.
    • During transit, avoid damage by protecting the cargo from exposure to seawater and weather, and also damage caused by improper lashing. Certain cargoes require ventilation during shipment and certain cargoes do not.
    • Ventilation is basically of two types:
      - Natural ventilation
      - Mechanical or forced draught ventilation
    • Container ships have been getting bigger since they began operating in liner services over 50 years ago because the increased size produces increased operating efficiency and improved environmental performance.
  • Learning Outcomes
  • Upon the successful completion of this module, you should be able to: 
    • Identify different aspects of ship operations in carrying maritime logistic processes.
    • Discuss the different chartering agreements. 
    • Outline the different classifications of the charter. 
    • Explain the concept of voyage chartering. 
    • Discuss the registration processes for ships. 
  • Aspects of Ship Operations 
  • During the 1960s, the liner shipping became increasingly unable to cope with the escalating volume of world trade. It is the advent of palletization and containerization that changed this scenario, and in doing so, opened the flood gates for rapid development of the global economy.

    Maritime Logistics is involved in carrying cargo in palletized, bulk and sealed containers. The development of these types of cargo carriage has resulted in reduced damage, loss and pilferage of cargo during transportation. This topic will deal with different aspects of ship operations in carrying maritime logistic processes.

  • The Voyage Charter
  • A voyage charter or spot charter involves the carriage of a specific amount and type of cargo from a load-port and carry to discharge-port. It is subjected to various cargo handling terms. Most of these charters are of a single voyage nature, as trading patterns do not encourage round voyage trading. The payment received by the owner of the vessel is derived by multiplying the tons of cargo loaded on board times the agreed-upon freight rate expressed on a per-ton basis. The owner is responsible for the payment of all expenses including voyage, operating and capital costs of the vessel.

    Chartering on a single voyage or a trip charter basis may be also referred to as spot charter. It is a contract for the use of a vessel for a specific voyage in which the shipowner pays substantially all of the vessel voyage costs which includes bunkers, port charges, stevedores charges and operating costs such as crew costs, insurance, stores, spares, lubes, repairs and maintenance.

    The freight is earned and accrued on completion of the contracted voyage or the voyage has been substantially performed. Generally, freight is paid on "right & true delivery".

It is a contract for the use of a vessel for a specific voyage in which the shipowner pays substantially all of the vessel voyage costs which includes bunkers, port charges, stevedores charges and operating costs such as crew costs, insurance, stores, spares, lubes, repairs and maintenance.

    The freight is earned and accrued on completion of the contracted voyage or the voyage has been substantially performed. Generally, freight is paid on "right & true delivery".
  • Registration
  • In order to operate internationally, a ship must be registered in a country, which will then permit the vessel to fly its flag. The country of registration will then become the ship’s "Flag State". 

    Registration is the process, whereby the ship entitled by the law of a Flag State is entered in the official register of the State, in the name of the Owner or Owners or the Bareboat Charterer.


    Registration of ships began as a practice to control the ships entitled to carry cargoes within the seaborne empires of Europe. 

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • However, in recent times, it has proved a convenient means of establishing title to the property in a vessel and serves to determine which country's law governs the operation of the vessel. Advantages of registration are many as shown in the concept map.

  • Lesson Summary
    • Maritime Logistics is involved in carrying cargo in palletized, bulk and sealed containers. The development of these types of cargo carriage has resulted in reduced damage, loss and pilferage of cargo during transportation.
    • Charter parties may be classed into four types:
      - Time charter
      - Voyage charter
      - Bareboat charter
      - Contract of affreightment
    • A Charter Party (C/P) is defined as a contract between a ship owner and charterers for the use of a ship or her cargo space. 
    • A voyage charter or spot charter involves the carriage of a specific amount and type of cargo from a load-port and carry to discharge-port.
    • A time charter is a contract for the use of a vessel for a specific period of time during which the charterer pays substantially all of the vessel voyage costs such as bunkers, port charges and stevedores charges. 
    • The bareboat or demise charter is the contract for the lease of a vessel, whereby the owner charters the vessel to another party, who runs it as if that party were the owner.
    • A contract of affreightment is a long term contract, where the cargo and not the vessel is central to the contract. 
  • Learning Outcomes
  • Upon the successful completion of this module, you should be able to:
    • Discuss the maritime chain of transportation.
    • Outline the various segments of the shipping market. 
    • Identify the roles of the shipping company or carrier. 
    • Discuss the roles of third-party service providers. 
    • Analyze the main assets of the freight forwarder. 
    • Explain the differences between tramp shipping and liner shipping. 
  • The Maritime Chain of Transportation
  • Transport is a derived demand of any business and “carriers and third-party service providers who engage in the chain of transportation, must derive value from and add value to the movement.In order to identify and categorize how different players create value 4 key metrics are:
    • Service
    • Quality
    • Cost
    • Time reduction
  • Any company – should focus on improving quality and service while reducing cycle time and cost to the consumer.

  • Agents of Affreightment
  • Liner shipping companies provide regular services between specified ports according to time-tables and prices advertised well in advance. The cargo is mainly carried by container liner companies, either in containers or as breakbulk. 

    Breakbulk is non-containerized general cargo, which is loaded individually (cars, paper reels and construction machinery etc.). The container lines will furthermore carry a vast number of different goods whereas bulk operators usually carry one single commodity.

    In liner shipping the transaction between the consignor/shipper and the carrier usually involves:
    • Freight Forwarders
    • Liner Agents

  • Difference Between Tramp Shipping and Liner Shipping 
  • Tramp shipping differs from liner shipping in several ways. Tramp operators are often referred to as the “taxis of the seas”. They have no fixed routes or schedules but are contract carriers who are hired on the spot market to transport cargo from any port to any port.

    The cargo usually consists of a large quantity of a single commodities; mainly dry bulk (ore, coal, fertilizer, grain etc.) carried in bulk carriers or wet bulk (usually crude oil, petrochemicals, gasoline etc.) carried in tankers. The cargo is thus usually of lower value than the (containerized) cargo carried by the liner companies.

    The terms of each individual charter are determined by negotiations between the consignor/shipper and the carrier, and basically reflects the immediate balance between supply and demand for specific types of ships (tankers, bulk carriers etc.). It may rightly be argued that dry bulk and wet bulk are very different in nature.

    Wet bulk can even be broken down into more specialized types of shipping e.g. crude oil tankers, product tankers and chemical tankers each carrying different types of cargo. In either case, however, the operator of a tramp ship must negotiate separate contracts for each employee of his vessel. In tramp shipping, it is usually an independent chartering broker who matches the consignor/shipper and the carrier.

  • Tramp shipping differs from liner shipping in several ways. Tramp operators are often referred to as the “taxis of the seas”. They have no fixed routes or schedules but are contract carriers who are hired on the spot market to transport cargo from any port to any port.

    The cargo usually consists of a large quantity of a single commodities; mainly dry bulk (ore, coal, fertilizer, grain etc.) carried in bulk carriers or wet bulk (usually crude oil, petrochemicals, gasoline etc.) carried in tankers. The cargo is thus usually of lower value than the (containerized) cargo carried by the liner companies.

    The terms of each individual charter are determined by negotiations between the consignor/shipper and the carrier, and basically reflects the immediate balance between supply and demand for specific types of ships (tankers, bulk carriers etc.). It may rightly be argued that dry bulk and wet bulk are very different in nature.

    Wet bulk can even be broken down into more specialized types of shipping e.g. crude oil tankers, product tankers and chemical tankers each carrying different types of cargo. In either case, however, the operator of a tramp ship must negotiate separate contracts for each employee of his vessel. In tramp shipping, it is usually an independent chartering broker who matches the consignor/shipper and the carrier.

  • Ports and Terminals 
  • When the consignor and the carrier(s) have agreed on a contract of affreightment the actual movement of the goods can commence. The transport from the production site to the port can be arranged and carried out by several players including shippers, freight forwarders, liner agents, shipping companies and inland carriers (trucks, trains, pipelines, conveyors etc.) depending on the cargo. The port operations will focus on how ports and terminal operators, and port agents add value in the maritime chain of transportation
  • Main assets:
    • Geographic location including Hinterland connections and access to major sea routes. 
  • Added value:
    • Time reduction and lower costs
      (Reduced sea - bound transportation time)
      (Reduced land - bound transportation time)
      (Reduced waiting time in port)
    • Lower costs 
      (Advantage of scale due to a large amount of cargo)
    • Improved service
      (Logistics chain integration service)
      (value-added facilities)

  • Third Party Ship Management
  • Shipping companies have traditionally managed their own ships. Starting around 1970s, many ship owners began outsourcing ship management to independent third parties. Third-party ship management has witnessed significant escalation in growth since the 1980s. Today, with approximately one-third of the world’s oceangoing fleet under third-party management of some kind, ship managers appear in many marine transactions for a multitude of reasons. For example:
    • Financial investors often appoint managers to provide comprehensive services to their acquired shipping assets which they are unable to otherwise provide in-house
    • Fully integrated ship owners may place some of their vessels under independent management as a means of benchmarking costs
    • Publicly listed ship owners may outsource ship management to address investor concerns and to achieve better overall risk management
    • Marine lenders often appoint managers to assume operational and technical control of a vessel that has been retaken following mortgage foreclosure and judicial sale
  • Third-party ship management services available in today's marketplace are varied, but the three most common forms are technical, crew and commercial management. Technical management typically involves the delivery of services relating to the maintenance, repair and running of the vessel, including compliance with flag state requirements and international operating standards. Crew management covers the selection, training, administration and transportation of the crew. Commercial management largely involves seeking and negotiating employment for the vessel.

    • Marine lenders often appoint managers to assume operational and technical control of a vessel that has been retaken following mortgage foreclosure and judicial sale
  • Third-party ship management services available in today's marketplace are varied, but the three most common forms are technical, crew and commercial management. Technical management typically involves the delivery of services relating to the maintenance, repair and running of the vessel, including compliance with flag state requirements and international operating standards. Crew management covers the selection, training, administration and transportation of the crew. Commercial management largely involves seeking and negotiating employment for the vessel.
  • Third Party Ship Management
  • Shipping companies have traditionally managed their own ships. Starting around 1970s, many ship owners began outsourcing ship management to independent third parties. Third-party ship management has witnessed significant escalation in growth since the 1980s. Today, with approximately one-third of the world’s oceangoing fleet under third-party management of some kind, ship managers appear in many marine transactions for a multitude of reasons. For example:
    • Financial investors often appoint managers to provide comprehensive services to their acquired shipping assets which they are unable to otherwise provide in-house
    • Fully integrated ship owners may place some of their vessels under independent management as a means of benchmarking costs
    • Publicly listed ship owners may outsource ship management to address investor concerns and to achieve better overall risk management
    • Marine lenders often appoint managers to assume operational and technical control of a vessel that has been retaken following mortgage foreclosure and judicial sale

  • Lesson Summary
    • Transport is a derived demand of any business and “carriers and third-party service providers who engage in the chain of transportation, must derive value from and add value to the movement.
    • The shipping market is basically made up of three segments:
      - Liner shipping
      - Bulk shipping
      - Specialized shipping
    • The shipping company or ship operator is a key player in the maritime chain of transportation. The shipping company adds value to the customer/consignor by transporting his goods from areas with supply to areas with demand.
    • The agents of affreightment are usually specialized in specific markets such as liner shipping, dry bulk or wet bulk etc. 
    • Liner shipping companies provide regular services between specified ports according to time-tables and prices advertised well in advance. 
    • The freight forwarder represents the consignor/shipper and takes on the responsibility of transporting the goods on his behalf. 
    • The chartering broker performs four types of services:
      - Searching for potential partners
      - Matching the agents
      - Assisting in the bargaining process between these agents
      - Taking care of the formalities in the contract
  • Learning Outcomes 
  • Upon the successful completion of this module, you should be able to:
    • Discuss the importance of ports and terminals. 
    • Analyze the complexity of port operations. 
    • Identify the different classifications of ports and terminals. 
    • Outline the various differences between ports and terminals. 
    • Explain the process of port operation management. 
  • Introduction to Ports and Terminals 
  • Ports are points between two domains of freight circulation, the land and maritime. The term port comes from the Latin Portus, which means gate or gateway. Ports are bound by the need to serve ships, and so access to navigable water has been the most important site consideration. Many major cities owed their early pre-eminence as port cities, such as London on the Thames, Montreal on the St. Lawrence River or Singapore on the Singapore Strait.

    As terminals, ports handle the largest amounts of freight, more than any other type of terminal combined. To handle this freight, port infrastructures jointly have to accommodate transshipment activities both on ships and inland and thus facilitate convergence between land transport and maritime systems. Considering the operational characteristics of maritime transportation, the location of ports is constrained to a limited array of sites, mostly defined by geography. Most ports, especially those that are ancient, owe their initial emergence to their site as the great majority of harbours are taking advantage of a natural coastline or a natural site along a river.

    The globalization of world trade has opened a particular competitive advantage to those countries or ports, (eg: Singapore, Amsterdam and Hong Kong) which can be used as a nodal point for transshipment of cargo and a distribution centre for the nearby regions and thus emerge as a hub port.

  • Port Classification
  • The very purpose of containerization was to reduce the number of port calls and the port stay, thereby enhancing the revenue earning potential of the ship. Although the original prediction that there will be one major load centre port on each coast of each trading region has not materialized, the number of port calls made by a container ship is substantially less than those of traditional liner ships.

    Commercial capabilities, trade practices, infrastructural capabilities and depth limitations have segregated container ports into various categories.

    There are the mega ports or gateway ports such as New York and Singapore that have grown to dominate the trade because of the port's strategic capabilities and location. 

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Then there are hub ports that attract mother ship services and from where feeder ships provide direct service to other nearby feeder ports. Thus, container commerce today is facilitated through a system of major and minor ports, all of which are integral to the system. The graph given above shows the top 10 container ports as of June 2005.
  • Please note: TEUs = 20-foot equivalent units. One 20-foot container equals one TEU.

  • Port Operations
  • In today's fast-paced economy driven by time-based competition and just-in-time inventory management systems, the efficiency of port and terminal operations is extremely crucial. While the entire system is built on the marine ISO containers and what is stowed inside those boxes, the speed and efficiency with which these boxes are handled at various stages determine the success or failure of the system. Accordingly, the very objective of container ports and terminals is to facilitate the uninterrupted and expedited flow of containers to interior points through its infrastructural and operational capabilities.

Accordingly, the very objective of container ports and terminals is to facilitate the uninterrupted and expedited flow of containers to interior points through its infrastructural and operational capabilities.

  • Introduction
  • A ship’s time in port will be referred to here as ship’s “port time”. Reduction in port time through the high-quality port operations allows shipping lines to improve the operational efficiency via reduced ship speed and thus fuel consumption. This calls for an examination of all aspects of port operation in order to find practical ways to cut down on ship port time.

    One possible way is to make a ship to operate Just-in-Time that involves getting rid of the waiting times in port. This will not only help to ship lines to get the maximum notice of berth availability but also facilitate the use of optimum ship speed at sea. Further, the reduction of berth time by improved cargo handling could be another way to reduce ship time in port.

    In this section, we will discuss the operational issues on how time in port affects the efficient ship operation in terms of operating costs, and methodologies for reducing not only the ship-in-port time but also improve other aspects of ship handling that could reduce a ship’s fuel consumption and hence reduced freight charges.

  • Lesson Summary
    • Ports are points between two domains of freight circulation, the land and maritime. The term port comes from the Latin Portus, which means gate or gateway. Ports are bound by the need to serve ships, and so access to navigable water has been the most important site consideration.
    • Major container ports have two key determinants. One is the centrality and the other, intermediacy.
    • Centrality refers to the port’s own business base, i.e., the containers originating and/or terminating in the port’s natural hinterland. Thus, ports located in areas with a huge population base typically have high centrality.
    • Intermediacy refers to a port’s ability to capture incremental traffic such as transshipment cargo or intermodal cargo whose final destination is elsewhere.
    • In addition to the public vs. private nature of container terminals, the terminals may be classified based on their method of container stowage. The two broad types of stowage are:
      - stacking system – uses less acreage for container stowage
      - chassis system – facilitates the expeditious movement of containers from the terminal area
    • Individual marine terminals are located within a port and are the locations where ships dock and cargo operations are performed.
    • Terminals are designed and operated to cater to specific types of ships and cargo modes. 
    • A port or terminal that does not offer such capability may be omitted from the transportation chain of the carrier's involved. Thus, ports and terminals are in a perennial effort to advance their intermodal and container handling capabilities and are investing huge sums of money for the same.
